Tosca later made her home in Ross, California, where she built a life centered on family, tradition, and enduring love. Tosca met the love of her life, Sergio Pardini, and they were married on February 17, 1952, at Saints Peter and Paul Church in North Beach. For sixty one adventure filled years they were inseparable and shared a deep devotion that guided their lives together. Known for her warmth, elegance, and quiet strength, Tosca created a home where everyone felt welcome. She was deeply proud of her Italian heritage and the traditions she lovingly passed down. Her kindness and grace touched all who knew her. Jan was born on October 31, 1931 in San Francisco to loving parents Alice Detour and Joseph Hettrick. Jan was a loving mother, grandmother and great grandmother who found her greatest joy in her family. She had a way of making people feel welcomed. She was kind, big hearted, extremely gracious and devoted to those she loved. Her presence will be deeply missed. Jan lived a long life traveling, playing golf, bunco with her friends and one of her greatest talents was to find a treasure at garage sales. In her final years she enjoyed playing penny slots at the casino. The last nine years Jan spent in the loving care of her daughter and son in law. A special thank you to her granddaughter Samantha for making her last days warm, comfortable and full of love. Jan survived by her daughter Tina Schilling (Michael), her grandchildren Michael (Marissa), Paul (Kacie), Samantha (Carlos), and her nine great grandchildren Jackson, Aubrey, Jordan, Mikey, Ellie, Luna, Ryder, Makayla and Stella. Survived by her husband of 41 years, Phil Schlosser, her mother Gerry, daughter Kelly Noel, son Kevin Noel and wife Jennifer and her grandchildren Trevor and Lena. Her great adventure was moving to Mexico, building a wonderful home filled with warmth, family, friends and great meals. She loved traveling throughout Mexico and Italy. Representative_Docs: ['Asking Eric: Family, friends don’t seem to appreciate time I put into tedious Christmas cookie tradition Dear Eric: My late mother made a special Christmas cookie that required tedious decorating, considering each person’s personal preference for toppings, and giving them as gifts to family and friends. They always had a place of honor on our family Christmas table. When she was no longer able, she gave me the cookie cutter, and my daughters and I took over the family tradition. It takes the three of us several days to make, bake, decorate, package and mail cookies to family members around the country. We enjoy doing it and feel like we’re continuing the fun and festive tradition. However, in recent years, not all of the recipients acknowledge receipt. At some point in their lives, they have all helped Grandma decorate, so they know the time involved. Because of past delivery issues, I track the boxes and inquire if I haven’t heard from them in a couple of days. Last year, one response was “yes we got them.” This feels unappreciative! In the past most would text a picture of their children with the cookies, which we really enjoyed. We rarely see any of them anymore, as they are busy raising their families and don’t live nearby. This seems like a way for us to continue somewhat of a co', 'Asking Eric: Can mom work through tension in son’s relationship with dad so they can celebrate special birthday? Dear Eric: My son is turning 40 on December 22. My husband and I are at a quandary as to how to celebrate him. There have been issues between my husband and him over things from his childhood. We did a special trip for his older brother when he turned 40 and would like to do something special for this son’s 40th as well. Our daughter-in-law has made special plans for him and we are not included. I understand that, but I need some ideas as to how to celebrate this extra special year without rocking the boat. I love my son with all my heart, as I do all my children, and want his 40th birthday to be memorable in a positive way. Any suggestions? – Mom Who Wants to Celebrate Dear Mom: The issues your son and your husband are having may be an obstacle, but they aren’t insurmountable. And the thing that can get them on the path to resolution is the same thing that can get you answers about how to celebrate your son: open communication. It’s not within your purview to try to fix things between them, but you have your own relationship with your son and so I’d encourage you to reach out and tell him what you told me: you want to celebrate him, you know things are difficult, and you’re lookin', 'Asking Eric: After 6 years sober, man is frustrated by his family’s hold on their hurt and distrust Dear Eric: I’ve just turned 40 this past year. The last 15 years I was in a horrible drug addiction. I lied and hurt and did terrible things to a lot of people, especially my family. About eight years ago they officially disowned me. Understandable. I’ve cleaned up and got my act together six years ago. At first, I tried to force my way back into their lives, which all refuted. I lashed out, said horrible things and stopped trying to be in their lives. My mom will stop by on my birthday for 10 minutes or so and drop a card off at Christmas. As for my two older brothers and my father, it’s radio silence. I guess what I’m asking is, what do I do to fix this and fast, as I said I’ve turned 40 this year, my parents are both 70. Time is running out, and I couldn’t imagine living my life without some kind of acceptance from my father. Or knowing he did or does love me. My heart breaks at the thought, but this is a real pickle. How can I fix a problem when the ones I need to fix it with won’t talk to me? Do I just keep ignoring their existence and put on this façade that I don’t care to my wife and 4-year-old son? What picture am I painting to my son, as he’s been guilty by association yo']

Representative_Docs: ['‘UK public have tougher stance on immigration and diversity than people in US’ People in the UK are less likely than their US counterparts to feel diversity strengthens society and more likely to have tougher attitudes on immigration, according to research. The findings are said to show that a common narrative about Britain being more socially liberal than America does not ring true across all issues. The National Centre for Social Research also found Reform UK voters in Britain were more likely than supporters of President Donald Trump in the US to say immigrants living in their country without permission should not be allowed to stay. While seven in 10 supporters of Mr Trump felt this way, the figure was almost eight in 10 (79%) among Reform followers. The researchers said they wanted to “better understand how public attitudes in the UK compare with those in the US, and the extent of polarisation in the two countries”. Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. There is black, and then there is ultrablack. The shade defined as a black that reflects less than 0.5 percent of the light that hits it, is used on everything from telescopes to cameras. This uniquely dark color is not easy to produce and may appear less black when it is viewed at an angle. To find a better way to reproduce this cool color, a team at Cornell University looked to nature. Specifically, a bird called the magnificent riflebird. The magnificent riflebird is a large songbird and member of the bird-of-paradise family found in New Guinea and Australia. Representative_Docs: ["England completes perfect World Cup qualifying campaign TIRANA, Albania — Perfect England is heading to the World Cup with a 100 per cent qualifying record. A 2-0 win against Albania on Sunday made it eight wins from eight for Thomas Tuchel's team, which also booked its place in next year's tournament without conceding a goal. England had already qualified before completing its final Group K match, but finished in style with another win. All-time leading scorer Harry Kane hit both goals in Tirana to extend his record to 78 goals in 112 games for his country. “We’ve set the standard now, especially in the last few camps,” the England captain told broadcaster ITV. “We're going to go into the tournament as one of the favourites. We have to accept that, it's been like that for the last few tournaments.” Kane's record in all competitions for Bayern Munich and England this season stands at 25 goals in 18 appearances. Representative_Docs: ["Strictly Come Dancing star confesses to feelings of 'guilt' about winning BBC show Karen Carney, George Clarke and Amber Davies will battle it out for the coveted Glitterball trophy on Strictly Come Dancing this weekend, with YouTuber George currently leading as the bookmakers' favourite. Yet the competition doesn't always go according to plan, with the BBC ballroom series having witnessed numerous surprising outcomes throughout its history. The 2009 series delivered one of the programme's most unexpected moments when Chris Hollins defied the odds to triumph over favourite Ricky Whittle. The victory surprised many, with the presenter later admitting he felt somewhat guilty about his win too. Hollyoaks actor Ricky, partnered with professional dancer Natalie Lowe, had regularly out-danced Chris, who performed alongside Ola Jordan.
